column5: message

lint: remove the var decl check

Removes the var decl check which often fires when the type is required
for documentation purposes. For example, when an enumerated list of
pre-defined values of a certain type is created, it may be desirable to
group those values under the type itself in the docs. If the type is
infered, godoc will not group them, but if the type is manually listed
they will be placed in the correct location.

Since this lint is not an important stylistic consideration and
frequently produces false positives, removing it is consistent with the
scope of lints in this project.

Fixes golang/lint#429

Change-Id: I2afd928eae0bb11b39886c045556cda0771e3af5
Reviewed-on: https://go-review.googlesource.com/c/lint/+/191317
Run-TryBot: Sam Whited <sam@samwhited.com>
TryBot-Result: Gobot Gobot <gobot@golang.org>
Reviewed-by: Andrew Bonventre <andybons@golang.org>

Improve installation instructions for Go beginners

As a mentor at `exercism.io` I have to explain again and again how to install `golint`. Being new to Go they don't know where `golint` is installed and how to get it to work if they get the error message: `command not found`.

all: re-introduce go.mod and go.sum files

Now that tools' dependencies have been cleaned up in golang.org/cl/160837, lint
doesn't have any transitive dependencies on modules that import it using the
wrong path. It is now safe to reintroduce a go.mod file to this repo. I've
checked using dmitshur's instructions in
https://github.com/golang/lint/issues/436#issuecomment-469048301 that lint only
appears with its canonical module path in the build list.

Updates golang/lint#436

Revert "all: add a go.mod file"

This reverts commit 5b3e6a55c961c61f4836ae6868c17b070744c590.

Adding a go.mod file has started to cause go get -u golang.org/x/lint
to fail in module mode. This is issue golang/lint#436. Remove the
go.mod file for now in order to resolve the issue. We will re-add
the go.mod file to this repository again when it's a better time
to do so.

all: add a go.mod file

This change adds a go.mod and go.sum file to this repo, following the
requirements stated in bcmills's comment here:
https://golang.org/issue/28136#issuecomment-462971974. It's
important to note that we will not be
adding versions to the repo for now.

The change was generated by running "go mod init" and "go mod tidy" using Go
1.11.5 in the top-level directory of the repository.

Updates golang/go#28136

Change-Id: I5bdb5ea44cd65042afeef675a0c3bfaa6d3c65ea

Run-TryBot: Michael Matloob <matloob@golang.org>
TryBot-Result: Gobot Gobot <gobot@golang.org>
Reviewed-by: Dmitri Shuralyov <dmitshur@golang.org>

go/lint: only report kBlah error for constants and top level vars

The error for variables that start with k followed by a variable name,
such as "kBlah", has a lot of false positives. It's intended to avoid
cases where users try to follow the Google C++ style guide or hungarian
notation for constants. So it should only be reported for constants and
top-level variables because those are the cases where users make this
mistake.

Change-Id: Ic639e29cafa0152ba61b222915261c37992ed71f

Reviewed-by: Andrew Bonventre <andybons@golang.org>

lint: allow multiple error return values

When returning multiple values with an error,
lint checks if the error is the last return value.
But the implementation actually is checking for all return values
except for the last one, and throw the alert if it found an error.

There is a (edge) case where some function returning more than one error
is getting a false positive even when the last return value is an error.

This patch adds an early check, to see if the last return value is an error
and if so, it will pass silently.

Fixes golang/lint#286

Change-Id: Ib3ad50ed127cdab6ac63e9d89c1c97f4a641f972
GitHub-Last-Rev: 9dd9de4fce5fccc846d010cc1c57720e33da85aa
GitHub-Pull-Request: golang/lint#387
Reviewed-on: https://go-review.googlesource.com/99295
Reviewed-by: Andrew Bonventre <andybons@golang.org>

lint: avoid false positives with custom errors-package

When using `errors.New(fmt.Sprintf(...))`,
lint will alert that you should use `fmt.Errorf(...)`.

Before this patch, this alert was also displayed
when using a custom errors-package.
There are valid use cases to use `errors.New(fmt.Sprintf(...))`
in a custom errors-package context.

This patch avoids the "false positive" alert
when a custom errors-package is imported in the current file.

Fixes golang/lint#350

Add check for MixedCaps in package name

Lint already checks for underscores in package names, but did not yet
check for lower case names. The section on Package names in the
Effective Go document states that "By convention, packages packages are
given lower case, single-word names; there should be no need for
underscores or mixedCaps."

Updated .travis.yml (#343)

Added the latest Go version: 1.9

Specify exact license in header of Emacs lisp library (#353)

* Emacs: specify exact license in library header

Emacs packages are often distributed by themselves (e.g. on Melpa
and the Emacsmirror) even when they are developed in a repository
that other files beside the Elisp libraries.  In such cases it
should still be possible to tell what the license is, so replace
"BSD-style license" with "BSD-3-clause" and use the standard
"License" header keyword to do so.

* Emacs: cleanup whitespace

* Emacs: golint: wrap and slightly improve doc-string
Update README.md
Update README.md
Update README.md to clarify scope of golint

Test for using errors.New with a capitalized string (#368)

Add a test for the "error strings should not be capitalized" warning when using `errors.New`.

To be honest, I don't know if this will pass or not; I assume it will.
Add Go 1.9 to Travis testers (#365)

Remove unused `isZero` func (#364)

`isZero` unused since 4e7ffd8.

Improve receiver name underscore message. (#314)

Remind users that they can omit a receiver name entirely instead of
using an underscore for an unused receiver argument.
Fixes #310.

Check for redundant if err != nil constructs. (#319)

* Check for redundant if err != nil constructs.

Detect and complain about constructs like:

if err := foo(); err != nil {
  return err
}
return nil

(Issue https://github.com/golang/lint/issues/312)

* Rewrite lintIfError without using matchers.

Also don't emit lint errors if there are any comments explaining the
construct (between if and return statements).

Fix lint on packages with all generated files

A package with all generated files will reduce to a set with no
source files, which causes lint to panic on a nil-pointer dereference.
Move the conditional check for an empty package until after we
have checked the package for generated files.

Fixes #300

Ignore generated code

Fixes #239

Update .travis.yml for latest conventions, use fast_finish, test with -race. (#279)

* Update .travis.yml for latest conventions, use fast_finish, test with -race.

This change follows #277, but updates .travis.yml to use latest
conventions as documented at https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/languages/go#Specifying-a-Go-version-to-use.
Specifically, use master instead of tip to refer to latest (unreleased)
version of Go.

Use .x to target latest patch releases of each point release of Go.

Use fast_finish to speed up build reporting with no semantic change.
It's documented at https://blog.travis-ci.com/2013-11-27-fast-finishing-builds/.

Use race detector when running tests.

* Update .travis.yml to migrate from legacy to container-based infrastructure.

If lint doesn't do anything that would require sudo access,
it's a good idea not to require sudo access. This allows the builds
to run on Travis' newer container-based infrastructure, which
are not considered legacy and should run faster.
See https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/migrating-from-legacy/ for details.
Update travis for go1.8 + tip (#277)

Suppress underscore warning for cgo functions

This change suppresses the warning for functions which are:
1. exported to C via a cgo "//export" comment, and
2. not exported in the Go package.

That allows functions exported to C to use idiomatic C names, but
still requires that they not pollute the exported Go API.

Fixes #144
Fix minor typos.

Support multiple packages and directories

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>

Ignore invalid types as keys in context.WithValue

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>
Stop using deprecated gcimporter15 package

Flag error strings that end with a newline

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>
Add check for argument position of context variable.

Remove check for 0-length make.

While a 0-length make is sometimes done when a user should
have used "var s []int", the current lint check is reported to
cause too many false positives on legitimate uses of 0-length make.
This occurs because there is a semantic difference between
"make([]int, 0)" and "var s []int".

Fixes #234

Remove me from list of bad receivers.

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>
Configure Travis to use Go1.7.

Drop support for Go 1.5.

Disallow basic types as keys in context.WithValue().

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>

Avoid type-inference warnings due to partial type info.

Fix crash on ill-formed receiver type.

Signed-off-by: Joe Tsai <joetsai@google.com>
Add ACL as a common initialism.
Explicitly whitelist LastInsertId and kWh as exempt from the naming checks.

golint: Add a flag to cause a non-zero exit when suggestions are made.

Fixes #65.
Update golint's copy of the part of cmd/go required for matching package patterns like "std".

Split (importer).ImportFrom into its own build-tag-guarded file.

This keeps the lint package building with Go 1.5.
Explicitly check golint build on Go 1.5 and Go 1.6.

Switch to the go/types API in the standard library.

This means that golint now requires Go 1.5 or later.
It also means that vendored packages will now be correctly handled,
assuming you are using Go 1.6 or later.

Fixes #151.

Fix lint check for ValueSpec docs.

For standalone package-global var/consts, there is still a GenDecl
with no parens, and the var/const's doc comment may be attached to
that instead of to the ValueSpec.

Fixes #166.

Fix a typo: lineMake -> lintMake

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Lint files that use cgo.

go/build separates Go files into two categories (not counting test
files): pure Go files (GoFiles), and files that use cgo (CgoFiles).

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Revert "Add unitless duration lint check."

This reverts commit b55059174c9f0cda51e7a12038ba79644d158bf3.

It turned out to have too many false positives.

Add unitless duration lint check.

Fixes #130.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Avoid panicking on a method-less receiver.

This is malformed Go code that go/parser accepts;
handle the situation gracefully.

Fixes #134.
Update obsolete code.google.com references.
Add SQL as a common initialism.

Expand suggestions to cope with sub-line replacements.

This changes the Errorf check to provide a suggestion.

Fix link to CodeReviewComments wiki page.

Fixes #131.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Fix to follow some recent changes to the go/types API.

Implement suggested replacements for problems.

This adds the infrastructure for plumbing suggestions through,
and implements a suggested fix for range-loop.

Add links to style guides.

Fixes #125.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Emacs package: Quote command arguments.

This allows using the Emacs package with file names containing shell
metacharacters.

Fixes #83

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Fix panic in t.Errorf check if the typechecker fails.

Fixes #116.

Check for `t.Error(fmt.Sprintf(...))` where t is a *testing.T.

Suggest replacing it with `t.Errorf(...)`.

Fixes #115.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Improve Structure and Formatting of README.

* The installation instructions were too easy to miss (I missed them)
* It’s a Markdown file but wasn’t using Markdown markup.

Fixes #113.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Avoid suggesting omitting the LHS type of a var decl for known weaker types.

This arises when type checking fails, and golint cannot determine
that the LHS and RHS are truly of different types. In that situation
it is an annoying false positive.
Add a categorisation for the lint warning for unexported types in APIs.

Add TCP and UDP as common initialisms.

Fixes #110.
Switch to a README.md so we can get a Travis CI build status badge.

Add configuration for Travis CI.

Fixes #77.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Update README to help ensure golint is installed with the latest dependencies.

Fixes #104.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Add a CONTRIBUTING.md file.
Add XSRF and XSS as common initialisms.

Attach "package comment is detached" warning to the gap.

It's more directly useful (the obvious fix is to delete the blank line).
Flag package comments that are detached from the package statement.

Update for API change in golang.org/x/tools/go/types.

Fixes #91.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Update stale links to reflect wiki move to GitHub.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Flag names of type time.Duration that have unit suffixes.

This catches people writing code such as
	var timeoutSecs = 5 * time.Second

Update to new Go subrepository import paths.

c.f. https://groups.google.com/d/msg/golang-nuts/eD8dh3T9yyA/l5Ail-xfMiAJ

Allow one underscore between digits.

Fixes #47

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Complain about exported functions/methods returning unexported types.

Implement "..." wildcard for packages and paths.

Fixes #58.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Sort problems.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Use file-level scope for untyped constant checking.

Fixes #61.

Avoid a confusing later panic if linting files across packages.

The usage declares that golint only accepts files from a single package,
so now we gracefully enforce that.

Fixes #63.

Use typechecker to recognise untyped constant expressions.

This lets us more accurately suppress type omission suggestions,
and also has the nice effect of throwing away some clumsy hacks.

This helps address #61, but doesn't completely fix it.
Hang on to the type information even when the typechecker fails.
Set a no-op error reporter to encourage the typechecker to do more work.

Avoid panic when an ast.Node is in a different file.

Fixes #59.

Permit linting of entire packages.

This gives the typechecker free reign in the open source world.

Fixes #43.

Use typechecked information to suppress type inference warning, where possible.

This does not solve false positives in every situation; notably it will
fail to work with multi-file packages; see #43.

Fixes #7.

Disable reporting of typechecking errors.

These are too noisy right now.

Fixes #57.

Hook up typechecker.

This does nothing with the extra information except warn if there's an error
returned by the typechecker (e.g. var not used).

This is the first step towards addressing #7.
Add reference link for stutter check.

Don't check for stutter of method names.

Method names are used object-qualified, not package-qualified.

Add GUID and UUID as common initialisms.

Fixes #55.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Add SMTP as common initialism.

Fixes #49.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Fix error message generated for kFoo names.

Fixes #46.
Add URI as a common initialism.
Flag names that stutter.
Provide lint problem categorisation.

Let golint ignore a function whose name starts "Benchmark" when it checks function declarations.

Fixes #44.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Add a blank line in a test so that gofmt won't break the magic comment's location.
Improve message for underscore receiver names.

Reduce confidence in error string leading capital check.

People often use proper nouns or exported Go identifiers in error strings,
which reduces the SNR for this check.
Check the param/result names of interface methods.

error output now compatible with vim quickfix

Prior to this change, read errors and parse errors would cause vim quickfix to
open new buffers with meaningless paths. For logged output, vim would open a new
buffer with the timestamp as a name.

This change makes some assumptions that are true today:
 * Errors from ioutil.ReadFile are user-readable and meaningful alone.
    e.g. open example.go: no such file or directory
 * Errors from parsing concatenate with the filename to produce quickfix format.
    e.g. example.go:8:1: expected declaration, found '}'

With this change, the suggested autosave behavior from the README is usable.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Recommend replacing "x := make([]T, 0)" with "var x []T".

The former is almost always pointless (it's often used immediately
before appending to x), and mainly due to a new Go programmer not
knowing that the zero value of a slice is equally good.
Add VM as a common initialism.

Don't lint names of interface methods.

They are often constrainted by the method names of concrete types,
so this check tends to have a high false positive rate.

Don't flag var typing when the RHS is an untyped constant
and the LHS type is not its default type.
Update link base to new location.
Add links to style guide.
Add SLA as a common initialism.

Add autoload cookie for lazy loading.

Fixes #34.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>

Emacs: ELPA compatibility

Fixes #33.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Minor refactoring.

Suggest replacing "x += 1" with "x++", and "y -= 1" with "y--".

This is a common mistake/oversight that ex-Python programmers make.
Add TTL as a common initialism.

Remove a TODO about supporting stdin.

Passing "/dev/stdin" works just fine.

Don't suggest removing a leading underscore.

lintName permits a single leading underscore, so we were returning messages such as
	don't use underscores in Go names; const _invalidJson should be _invalidJSON

Fixes #25.
Suggest moving short variable declarations to their own line if needed to keep normal code flow outdented.
Add a few more common initialisms: LHS, RHS, CPU, CSS, QPS, RAM.
Add DNS and UI as common initialisms.
Fix handling of digits adjacent to initialisms.

Add golint for emacs.

Fixes #19.
Fixes #23.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Check that error strings aren't capitalized and don't end with punctuation.
Check that names of global error vars are named like ErrFoo or errFoo.
Explain and strengthen warning about blank imports in libraries.
Check for inconsistent receiver names.
Add UID as a common initialism.
Check for receivers named 'this' or 'self'.
Check names of range vars and add more test cases for var declarations.
Check names of interface methods.
Don't check names in non-declaration assignment statements.
Check names of func/method arguments.
Suggest comment on const block for uncommented exported consts.
Don't flag multi-var declarations when only the first name is exported.

Simplify Vim setup instructions.

globpath assumes comma-separated entries, which $GOPATH does not provide
(it uses : or ; depending on the platform), and this is needlessly
general for most people anyway.

Fixes #14.

Compare golint and gofmt.

Fixes #13.

Add a lint warning for blank imports in library packages.

This adds a check to the golint tool for blank imports in library packages, if
those imports do not come with a documentation comment of some kind.  Only the
presence of a comment is checked, not its content.  Package main is exempt from
this check.

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Suggest replacing errors.New(fmt.Sprintf(...)) with fmt.Errorf(...).
Flag redundant range clauses.
Don't warn about negative/parenthesized int literals for non-int var decls.
Clarify that a reasonable response to a missing doc comment on an exported name is to unexport it.

allow underscores in test method names

Signed-off-by: David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org>
Add RPC as a common initialism.
Add Contributions section to README to point at the CLA.

Update README.

Show Lint result on saving .go files.

Flag ALL_CAPS and kLeadingKay names specifically so they get good messages.

Added the ability to scan directories recursively.

As a build step it's often useful to run a linter over your whole
project and see what needs linting.

Add installation instructions (again).
